Sargent Farmer Nation,
As most of you know, all spring sports and activities are postponed across Colorado and most of America. A movement started in Colorado recently where local high schools turn on their stadium lights for a short period of time at night to let students, coaches, parents and fans know that we are thinking of them in this difficult time, we will get through this and life, including sports and activities, will resume at some point.
So, if you see Sargent High School football field lights on and someone asks you what is going on, you can let them know that sports have not resumed yet, but we are thinking of Sargent Farmer Nation and all of the people that work so hard to make our many activities possible. Our lights will be on briefly tonight Tuesday, March 31, 2020
at approximately 8:30pm depending on how dark it is and then every Friday night at the same time.
We are proud to represent the entire Sargent Farmer Nation.

Dear Sargent Parents and Community,

It is with a heavy heart that we, the Sargent Staff, want to inform you of the passing of Mrs. Mary Garcia. Mary started at Sargent in 2002 as a custodial substitute. Then in 2004, she was hired as our librarian paraprofessional. In 2018, Mary was reassigned as the secondary administrative assistant. During her time in Sargent, she touched many hearts with her bubbly attitude and her huge heart for kids. The lasting connections she made with students and staff will be remembered for a long time.

There will be a Rosary service on Friday, September 13, 2019 at 7pm the Center Catholic Church and the funeral service will be on Saturday, September 14, 2019 at 10am again in Center at the Catholic Church.

A benefit dinner for the family to help with hospital and funeral expenses will be on Wednesday, September 18, 2019 at 6pm in the Sargent cafeteria. There will be a $5.00 potato bar dinner. Donations will also be accepted.

We would like congratulate and welcome Michelle (Shelley) David as the new Junior High and High School Principal starting fall of 2019. We look forward to having her as part of our administrative staff. Mrs. David has taught 1st, 5th, 6th, 9th, 10th, 11th and 12th grade in our district. Mrs. Cochran has been in the Sargent School District for 25 years. She also started in the elementary and moved her way up to the high school. We would like to wish Mrs. Cochran a happy retirement and we would like to thank her for all the years she has been in our community and school.

Sargent School District's Health and Wellness Plan committee is inviting all parents/guardians to a film on January 8 at 1:15 p.m. or 6:30 p.m. in the auditorium.

Screenagers is an award-winning film that probes into the vulnerable corners of family life and depicts messy struggles over social media, video games and academics. The film offers solutions on how we can help our kids navigate the digital world. Unlike other films Screenagers offers solutions to real-world problems we face daily.

Parents who attend will be entered into a drawing for several door prizes including $50 gift cards.

The 6th graders at Sargent Elementary recently entered an essay contest, for the third year in a row, sponsored by the Society of Women Engineers, and for the third year in a row, Sargent came out with awards. In past years, the award trail was blazed by now 8th graders, Ashlyn Rockey and Katherine Sewell, and now 7th grader, Megan Peterson. This year, there were 268 entrants from 14 schools across Colorado and Wyoming. 16 awards were given, and Sargent earned SIX of those awards!!! Honorable Merit awards (Top 8) went to Chloe Gerlach and Saige Hostetter, and Honorable Mention awards (Top 16) went to Gio Aguilar, Aaron Brimhall, Brooke Hoffstaetter, and Garett Thomson.

The 6th graders spent a month and a half doing research on one of five women of science or engineering. They visited the library at ASU, learned how to write a research essay, and bibliography, and helped each other to revise and edit.

Congratulations Sargent 6th graders! Well done!

Congratulations John Willis for being selected as Sargent School District's Teacher of the Year!!!

I am proud to be a San Luis Valley native, having been born and raised in Center. I graduated from Adams State University in 1995 with a BA in social studies education. I started my teaching career that year at Sargent. My wife Gina and I have been married almost twenty years, and have two amazing kids – Mary and Danny.
Over the years I have worked with students at a number of grade levels and settings. Early on, I taught junior high social studies and coached basketball, track and a little cross-country. Later, I moved up to high school social studies and became involved with sponsoring HS knowledge bowl, student council and history fair.
I have been privileged to work with, and learn from, some amazing educators at Sargent during my tenure there. I thank them for granting me the honor of representing Sargent School District this year.

ADM and Rio Grande Seed & Grain will be hosting a show feed clinic on Wednesday, March 14th at 6 pm, at Sargent School cafeteria.

Ginger has been in the feed industry for the past 16 years and has focused on feeding show livestock, giving clinics across the western states. She has a strong background coaching youth and is excited to be a part of our program.
The clinic will include, show livestock nutrition, livestock selection tips, what judges look for in the show ring, perfecting showmanship and preparing for fair.
Door prizes, pizza and beverages will be provided as well as some feed discounts for those who attend the clinic.
Contact Dimitrias Romero, Eric Kimberling, or Brett Hemmerling at 719-852-4088. Please RSVP by Noon, on March 13th.

Dear Parents,
This note is a short reminder of our illness policy which was previously sent out to you via school reach.
PLEASE do NOT send your child to school if they are vomiting or have a fever of 100 degrees or greater. In addition, excessive coughing is a disruption to their learning and to that of the class. Please DO NOT use fever reducing medicine and send them to school as if they are healthy. This is a violation of our policy and spreads illness.
They must stay home 24 hours after vomiting, fever, or starting antibiotics for contagious disease (such as Strep).
